 Regarding the question of to whom the state militias are answerable to, I understand the framework to be as follows (I use my beloved Commonwealth of Virginia in this example):
 
 Congress has the preemptive power:
 
 "To provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining, the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States, reserving to the states respectively, the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress" U.S. Constitution Art. 1, § 8 
 
 This organized, armed, and disciplined militia is answerable first to the civil state authority: 
 
 "That a well regulated militia, composed of the body of the people, trained to arms, is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a free state, therefore, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed; that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided as dangerous to liberty; and that in all cases the military should be under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power." Va. Constitution Art. 1 § 13
 
 That civil power is exercised by the Governor:
 
 "The Governor shall be commander-in-chief of the armed forces of the Commonwealth and shall have power to embody such forces to repel invasion, suppress insurrection, and enforce the execution of the laws."
 Va. Constitution Art. 5 § 7
 
 However, Congress also has the power at any time to "federalize" the state militia and place it under control of the federal government for the following purposes:
 
 "To provide for calling forth the militia to execute the laws of the Union, suppress insurrections and repel invasions" U.S. Constitution Art. 1, § 8 
 
 When this is done, the Governor loses his control over the militia, and the President assumes control:
 
 "The President shall be the commander in chief of the army and navy of the United States, and of the militia of the several states, when called into the actual service of the United States." U.S. Constitution Art. 2 § 2
 
 In the Militia Act of 1792 Congress effectively transferred its power of "calling forth the militia" to the president. The act gave standing authority to the President to call forth the militia into federal service without having to wait for Congress to do so in specific response to an emergency. The events permitting this standing Presidential authority are "whenever the United States shall be invaded, or be in imminent danger of invasion from any foreign nation or Indian tribe," and/or "whenever the laws of the United States shall be opposed or the execution thereof obstructed, in any state, by combinations too powerful to be suppressed by the ordinary course of judicial proceedings, or by the powers vested in the marshals by this act." 
 
 This was apparently done in response to fears that rebellion, invasion, or other troubles could occur while Congress was out of session or while Congress was in session but for other reasons prove too slow to react to the crisis.
